head.title: Fe and N Codoped Mesoporous Carbon Nanofiber as a Nonprecious Metal Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction and a Durable Support for Pt Nanoparticles | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Fe and N Codoped Mesoporous Carbon Nanofiber as a Nonprecious Metal Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction and a Durable Support for Pt Nanoparticles

Cost reduction and long-term durability are crucial issues for the commercialization of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells. To accomplish these goals, herein, we report an electrospun iron and nitrogen codoped mesoporous carbon nanofiber (Fe-N-MCNF) for use as both a low-cost nonprecious metal catalyst and a durable support of platinum nanoparticles. Silica nanoparticles and polyvinyl acetate are used together as porogens to create mesopores. As a synergetic effect of these two types of porogens, numerous mesopores are successfully formed inside of the carbon nanofibers. The highly mesoporous structure increases the specific surface area and improves the diffusion kinetics of the reactants, leading to an increase in the effective surface area of the Fe-N-MCNFs for electrochemical reactions. Therefore, the Fe-N-MCNFs can have high oxygen reduction reaction activity alone in an acidic solution and the ability to provide a large surface area for platinum nanoparticles as a support. The platinum nanoparticles on the Fe-N-MCNFs are highly stable under an oxidative potential condition of fuel cells due to the high corrosion resistance of the graphitized carbon structure. This work demonstrates that Fe-N-MCNF can be utilized as both a low-cost catalyst and a durable support in practical fuel cell applications.

div.p: Cost reduction and long-term durability are crucial issues for the commercialization of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells. To accomplish these goals, herein, we report an electrospun iron and nitrogen codoped mesoporous carbon nanofiber (Fe-N-MCNF) for use as both a low-cost nonprecious metal catalyst and a durable support of platinum nanoparticles. Silica nanoparticles and polyvinyl acetate are used together as porogens to create mesopores. As a synergetic effect of these two types of porogens, numerous mesopores are successfully formed inside of the carbon nanofibers. The highly mesoporous structure increases the specific surface area and improves the diffusion kinetics of the reactants, leading to an increase in the effective surface area of the Fe-N-MCNFs for electrochemical reactions. Therefore, the Fe-N-MCNFs can have high oxygen reduction reaction activity alone in an acidic solution and the ability to provide a large surface area for platinum nanoparticles as a support. The platinum nanoparticles on the Fe-N-MCNFs are highly stable under an oxidative potential condition of fuel cells due to the high corrosion resistance of the graphitized carbon structure. This work demonstrates that Fe-N-MCNF can be utilized as both a low-cost catalyst and a durable support in practical fuel cell applications.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: A new catalyst material with low cost and excellent durability was designed for sustainable energy production.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) have been considered as promising energy conversion devices due to their high efficiencies, high power densities, and low pollutant emission levels.
(1)
For high energy conversion efficiency by PEMFCs, carbon-supported platinum (Pt/C) is currently used to catalyze the electrochemical reactions at the electrodes, specifically the hydrogen oxidation reaction and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles on a carbon support can significantly reduce Pt usage in the electrodes without sacrificing the catalytic performance, but the high price and scarcity of Pt limit the large-scale application of PEMFCs. In addition, the conventional amorphous carbon support of Pt/C is vulnerable to corrosive attacks during the operation of the cell, which causes severe degradation of the PEMFC performance.
(2â4)
Therefore, it is important to explore low-cost and durable materials for the catalyst and support materials of PEMFC electrodes to realize cost reductions and to improve the long-term durability of PEMFCs for commercialization.

Carbonaceous materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and carbon nanofibers (CNFs) have been widely applied as novel catalysts and support materials for PEMFCs.
(5)
In early studies, these carbonaceous materials were mainly considered as attractive alternatives to the amorphous carbon support of Pt/C because their crystalline structures are more stable than that of the amorphous carbon support under the oxidative environments of PEMFCs.
(6,7)
However, given the recent reports that transition metals and nitrogen codoping into the crystalline carbon structure (M-N-C) give rise to ORR functionalities,
(8â10)
carbonaceous materials are also becoming attractive as inexpensive nonprecious-metal catalysts for PEMFCs.
(11â13)

Among the carbonaceous materials, CNFs offer the advantage of compatibility with industrial mass production due to the graphitization of electrospun polymer nanofibers. The most commonly used polymer precursor for CNFs is polyacrylonitrile (PAN). Graphitized CNFs from PAN nanofibers have high mechanical strength and high resistance to corrosion. Moreover, the fibrous texture of one-dimensional (1D) CNFs enables the creation of porous structures for efficient mass transport when applied as support materials for PEMFC electrodes. In addition, the nitrogen atoms in the nitrile group of PAN can be doped into CNFs during the carbonization process. Consequently, PAN-derived CNFs without additional nitrogen sources are affordable for the creation of ORR active M-N-C structures.
(8,14â18)
As such, electrospun PAN-derived CNFs have many favorable characteristics likely required for use as both nonprecious-metal catalysts and durable supports for PEMFC electrodes. However, the electrochemical performances of current CNF-based catalysts must be improved in order to ensure the practical use of PEMFCs, whether as nonprecious catalysts or durable supports. The low electrochemical performances of catalysts are often related to the lack of an effective surface on which electrochemical reactions can take place, as CNFs have relatively larger diameters (â¼500 nm) than other carbonaceous materials, such as graphene and CNTs.

Introducing the mesoporosity is an effective way to modify the structure of CNFs. A high density of mesopores (2â50 nm) can increase the specific surface area of CNFs and improve the diffusion kinetics inside the CNFs.
(19,20)
These features are expected to increase the effective surface areas of CNF-based catalysts to facilitate electrochemical reactions. Moreover, a mesoporous structure is beneficial when used as a support as it provides a large surface area for a uniform distribution of catalyst nanoparticles. Mesoporous structures have excellent potential to maximize the electrochemical performances of CNF-based catalysts as both nonprecious-metal catalysts and durable supports. However, mesoporous CNF-based catalysts that are made using facile electrospinning have rarely been reported. Some electrospun CNF-based catalysts with micropores and small mesopores (<10 nm) have been reported, but their catalytic activities did not significantly improve.
(15,16,21)
Small micro- and mesopores cannot provide a sufficient size of diffusion channels for reactants; hence, most of the inner region areas of the CNFs remain electrochemically inactive despite the additional pores.

Herein, we report iron-nitrogen codoped mesoporous CNFs (Fe-N-MCNFs) as both nonprecious-metal catalysts and durable supports for PEMFCs. A typical approach to create a porous structure is to use a porogen. The pore size and architecture of a porous structure strongly depend on the porogen materials used. In this study, we used two types of porogens together to make mesoporous CNFs: silica nanoparticles and polyvinyl acetate (PVAc). Silica nanoparticles (14 nm primary particle size) were used as the main porogen to make mesopores in CNFs. PVAc was used as a secondary porogen to help with mesoporous structuring. During the carbonization of the PAN nanofibers, polymeric PVAc was decomposed to make additional micropores, which can assist with the subsequent dissolution of silica nanoparticles from the CNFs by providing channels through which a leaching solution can penetrate to the inside of the CNFs. In this way, high densities of mesopores, whose sizes were from 10 to 100 nm, were formed while maintaining the 1D structure of the CNFs. In order to assess the feasibility of the Fe-N-MCNFs under PEMFC operating conditions for use as low-cost and durable materials in PEMFC electrodes, the prepared Fe-N-MCNFs were investigated as both nonprecious-metal catalysts for the ORR and as durable supports for Pt nanoparticles. The ORR activities and durabilities of the Fe-N-MCNFs and Pt nanoparticles deposited onto the Fe-N-MCNFs were evaluated in comparison with those of nonporous iron-nitrogen codoped CNFs (Fe-N-CNFs) and the conventional Pt/C under the oxidative condition of PEMFCs.

div.div:
The silica nanoparticles, anhydrous
N
,
N
-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.8%), PVAc (
M
w
= 50000), PAN (
M
w
= 150000), iron(III) acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)
3
, 97%), and chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H
2
PtCl
6
Â·6H
2
O, ACS reagent, â¥37.50% Pt basis) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The commercial Pt/C catalyst used in this study (20 wt %, 2 nm Pt NPs on Vulcan XC-72) was purchased from Premetek Company.

Fe-N-MCNFs were synthesized by the leaching of silica nanoparticles followed by electrospinning and carbonization of Fe and a silica-containing polymer solution. The silica nanoparticles were added to DMF and then sonicated for 30 min to ensure a uniform dispersion. Fe(acac)
3
, PVAc, and PAN were added to the silica-dispersed DMF solution, which was then stirred for 6 h at 45 Â°C to melt the PVAc and PAN completely. The prepared solution was electrospun at a high voltage of 17 kV with an injection rate of 30 Î¼L min
â1
. The electrospun nanofibers were stabilized at 230 Â°C for 3 h in an air gas atmosphere and then carbonized at 900 Â°C for 1 h in an Ar gas atmosphere. The silica nanoparticles in the CNFs were dissolved away by stirring at 60 Â°C in a 1 M NaOH solution for 8 h. After the leaching process, the sample was filtered by deionized (DI) water to wash completely away any residual alkaline solution, after which they were dried at 60 Â°C under a vacuum condition for a day. After the second heat treatment at 900 Â°C for 1 h in an Ar gas atmosphere, the Fe-N-MCNFs were synthesized.

Nonporous Fe-N-CNFs were synthesized through a procedure similar to that used with the Fe-N-MCNFs. Fe(acac)
3
and PAN were added to DMF and then stirred for 6 h at 45 Â°C. The prepared solution was electrospun at a high voltage of 17 kV with an injection rate of 30 Î¼L min
â1
. The electrospun nanofibers were stabilized at 230 Â°C for 3 h in an air gas atmosphere and then carbonized at 900 Â°C for 1 h in an Ar gas atmosphere. To remove inactive metallic components, the CNFs underwent an acid-leaching process at 80 Â°C in 0.5 M H
2
SO
4
for 6 h. After the leaching process, the sample was filtrated by DI water to completely wash out the residual acidic solution and then dried at 60 Â°C under a vacuum condition for a day. After the second heat treatment at 900 Â°C for 1 h in an Ar gas atmosphere, the Fe-N-CNFs were synthesized.

Pt deposition on Fe-N-MCNFs (Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs) was conducted using a polyol reduction method. The prepared Fe-N-MCNFs were added to ethylene glycol and then sonicated for a uniform dispersion. H
2
PtCl
6
Â·6H
2
O was added to the Fe-N-MCNFs dispersed solution. The Pt precursor was reduced by refluxing the solution by means of mechanical stirring at 130 Â°C for 3 h. After the reduction process, the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs were washed with ethanol and then dried at 60 Â°C under a vacuum condition for a day. Finally, the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs were heat-treated at 200 Â°C for 1 h in an Ar gas atmosphere to remove any residual organic impurity.

The general morphology was examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping was conducted to examine the elemental distribution of the CNFs before and after the leaching of the silica nanoparticles. A phase analysis was conducted via X-ray diffraction (XRD). The chemical states of the doped N in the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS results were calibrated using a CâC bond of 284.8 eV as a reference. To measure the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas and pore volume distributions of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs, all samples underwent a pretreatment at 200 Â°C for 1 h under vacuum. Raman spectroscopy was conducted using a 514 nm laser beam and a charge coupled device detector with a 4 cm
â2
resolution to characterize the properties of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs.

All electrochemical experiments were conducted using a standard three-compartment cell. A glassy carbon (GC) electrode, Pt wire, and a silver/silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) electrode were used as the working, counter, and reference electrodes, respectively. The catalyst ink slurries were prepared by mixing the catalysts with DI water and 5 wt % Nafion solution as a binding material. After mixing and ultrasonication, a drop of the catalyst ink slurry was loaded onto a GC substrate and then dried. All potentials were referenced against a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The potential difference between the Ag/AgCl electrode and the RHE was obtained from a cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve measured in a hydrogen-saturated solution with a Pt disc as the working electrode. The sweep rate was 1 mV s
â1
.

The ORR experiments were conducted by means of CV measurements in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH and 0.1 M HClO
4
solutions. The potential range was 0.05 to 1.0 V
RHE
at a sweep rate of 5 mV s
â1
, and the rotation speed of the working electrode was 1600 rpm. For a rotating-ring disc experiment (RRDE), 1.4 V
RHE
was applied to the Pt ring of the working electrode during the ORR experiments. The hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) yield and electron transfer number for the ORR were calculated based on
eqs S1 and S2
. As an accelerated test for the M-N-C catalyst, potential cycling from 0.6 to 1.1 V
RHE
was conducted in an O
2
-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
solution at a scan rate of 50 mV s
â1
. As an accelerated test to simulate the oxidative environment of PEMFCs, potential cycling from 0.6 to 1.3 V
RHE
was conducted in an Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
solution at a scan rate of 50 mV s
â1
. Contamination of the working electrode by dissolution of the Pt counter electrode was almost negligible during the potential cycling test (
Table S1
). The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the Pt nanoparticles was calculated based on the H
2
desorption area of the CV curve measured in an Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
solution at a scan rate of 50 mV s
â1
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Figure
1
a shows electrospun PAN-PVAc nanofibers containing the Fe precursor and silica nanoparticles before carbonization. The as-spun nanofibers exhibited a 1D fibrous structure with a uniform thickness. The thickness of the nanofibers is approximately 500 nm. After the heat treatment at 900 Â°C under the Ar gas condition, the as-spun nanofibers were carbonized but maintained their 1D fibrous structures, as shown in
Figure
1
b. Some particles were observed on the surfaces of the CNFs. These particles were likely exposed silica nanoparticles due to the volume shrinkage of the as-spun nanofibers during the carbonization step. It is known that hydrogen, nitrogen, and some amount of carbon atoms evaporate from PAN during carbonization, causing losses of the mass and volume.
(14)
Therefore, the embedded silica nanoparticles in the as-spun nanofibers would be exposed to the surface after carbonization. The TEM-EDS mapping analysis results in
Figure
2
aâd show that numerous silica nanoparticles were embedded in the CNFs. High densities of Si and O elements for silica nanoparticles were observed inside the CNFs. In contrast, after a leaching process in the 0.1 M NaOH solution, the Si and O mapping images did not exhibit any distinct features that could define the CNF region (
Figure
2
fâj), indicating that nearly all of the silica nanoparticles were dissolved away. However, most of the Fe elements in the CNFs did not dissolve during the leaching process, as shown in
Figure
2
e,j. These mapping results imply that leaching of the embedded silica nanoparticles created a high density of mesopores inside the CNFs without damaging the Fe elements.

div.p: Figure 1. (a) As-spun and (b) carbonized PAN-PVAc nanofibers containing silica nanoparticles and Fe as a precursor.
Figure 2. TEM-EDS mapping images of the Fe-N-MCNFs (aâe) before and (fâj) after the silica nanoparticle leaching step.

div.div:
The TEM images clearly show the pores in the CNFs that were formed during the carbonization and leaching processes.
Figure
3
a shows the Fe-N-CNFs synthesized from the PAN nanofibers containing only a Fe precursor, without porogen materials. The Fe-N-CNFs have nonporous structures containing only some Fe-based nanoparticles. The Fe-based nanoparticles are revealed to be iron carbide (Fe
3
C; JCPDS 65-2413), as shown in
Figure S1
, which commonly forms in pyrolyzed Fe-N-C catalysts.
(13,22,23)
Unlike the Fe-N-CNFs, many small pores were observed after the carbonization of the PAN-PVAc nanofibers containing the Fe precursor and silica nanoparticles (
Figure
3
b). These small pores derived from the decomposition of the PVAc during the carbonization and could not only increase the porosity in the CNFs but also augment the leaching of the silica nanoparticles by providing additional channels through which the leaching solution can permeate into the embedded silica nanoparticles. This would explain why nearly all of the embedded silica nanoparticles can be dissolved away after the leaching process, as shown in the TEM-EDS mapping images. Therefore, due to the synergetic effect of the two types of porogen materials, our Fe-N-MCNFs would have highly mesoporous structures, as shown in
Figure
3
c,d. In consequence, numerous 10â20 nm sized mesopores were observed in the Fe-N-MCNFs.

div.p: Figure 3. TEM images of (a) the Fe-N-CNFs and the Fe-N-MCNFsÂ (b) before (c), and (d) after the leaching of silica nanoparticles.

div.div:
The pore structures of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs were further analyzed in detail by means of the BET method.
Figure
4
a shows the N
2
adsorptionâdesorption isotherms (BET) of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs. The isotherm of the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited a type-H
3
hysteresis loop according to the IUPAC classification.
(24)
Type-H
3
hysteresis is usually found in porous solids with a very wide variety of pore sizes.
(25)
Indeed, the pore volume distribution graphs (
Figure
4
b) show that the Fe-N-MCNFs have a wide range of mesopores from 4 to 100 nm. Main peaks were observed at pore sizes of approximately 4, 10, and 30 nm. The sharp peaks of the Fe-N-MCNFs observed at pore diameters of about 4 and 10 nm show that pores will form due to the decomposition of PVAc and the dissolution of single silica nanoparticles, respectively. In addition, some silica nanoparticles can exist in an agglomerated form, which could lead to the formation of differently sized mesopores at more than 10 nm after the leaching process.
Figure S2
shows that the number of mesopores inside the Fe-N-MCNFs was maximized through the use of silica nanoparticles and PVAc together. These pore structure analysis results clearly demonstrate that the Fe-N-MCNFs have highly mesoporous structures due to the synergetic effect of the silica nanoparticles and PVAc, as noted above. Unlike the Fe-N-MCNFs, the Fe-N-CNFs exhibited a very low volume of the N
2
adsorptionâdesorption isotherm (
Figure
4
a) and no notable pores (
Figure
4
b). Therefore, there is a major difference in the BET surface area between the two samples, that is, the Fe-N-MCNFs (416.8 m
2
g
â1
) and the Fe-N-CNFs (232.1 m
2
g
â1
). The Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited a BET surface area 1.8 times larger than that of the Fe-N-CNFs due to their highly mesoporous structures.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) N
2
adsorptionâdesorption isotherms and (b) pore volume distributions of the Fe-N-MCNFsÂ and the Fe-N-CNFs.

div.div:
The Raman spectra were assessed to determine the carbon structures of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs samples. As shown in
Figure
5
a, two sharp peaks corresponding to the D and G bands of the graphene-like carbon structure were observed at about 1350 and 1590 cm
â1
in the Raman spectra of the Fe-N-MCNF and the Fe-N-CNF samples. The D peak corresponds to the breathing modes of the six-atom rings and occurs at the defect sites of the carbon sheets, and the G peak corresponds to the high-frequency E
2g
mode of graphite.
(26,27)
The relative intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (
I
D
/
I
G
) typically represents the defect density within the carbon structure. There were only minor differences in the
I
D
/
I
G
values between the Fe-N-MCNFs (1.14) and the Fe-N-CNFs (1.17), but those values were higher than that of the CNFs (
Figure S3
,
I
D
/
I
G
: 0.98) without Fe doping. The higher
I
D
/
I
G
values can be ascribed to the increased defect density due to Fe and N doping into the carbon structure. The nearly identical
I
D
/
I
G
values of the Fe-N-MCNFs and Fe-N-CNFs indicate that they have almost the same heteroatom doping contents in their carbon structures. The EA analysis results confirm that the two samples have nearly identical N doping contents, with the Fe-N-MCNFs at 2.77 at. % and the Fe-N-CNFs at 2.76 at. %. However, there was a notable difference in the 2D band of approximately 2000 cm
â1
between them in that the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited a 2D peak with an increased intensity relative to that of the Fe-N-CNFs. The relative intensity ratio of the G band to the 2D band (
I
G
/
I
2D
) is typically used to estimate the number of layers of graphene. It is known that the
I
G
/
I
2D
value is inversely proportional to the number of layers of graphene.
(28)
CNF is a type of pyrolytic carbon with a graphitic structure. Although the stacking of carbon layers in the CNFs is not precisely identical to that of multilayer graphene or pure graphite, the
I
G
/
I
2D
values of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs may also be related to the number of carbon layers in their graphitic structures. The
I
G
/
I
2D
value of the Fe-N-MCNFs (3.87) is lower than that of the Fe-N-CNFs (6.36), indicating that the graphitic structure of the Fe-N-MCNFs is composed of fewer carbon layers than that of the Fe-N-CNFs. This result can be ascribed to the mesoporous structuring realized through silica leaching. Silica nanoparticles can hinder the thick stacking of carbon layers during the carbonization process by occupying a large volume in the CNFs. Therefore, the Fe-N-MCNFs have graphitic structures with fewer carbon layers than the Fe-N-CNFs, which would be exhibited in the Raman spectra as a 2D peak with an increased intensity level.

div.p: Figure 5. (a) Raman spectra and (b) XPS N 1s spectra of the Fe-N-MCNFsÂ and the Fe-N-CNFs.

div.div:
This difference in the stacking of carbon layers affects the chemical states of the doped N in the CNFs.
Figure
5
b shows the XPS N 1s spectra of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs. Both samples exhibited pyridinic N and graphitic N that are doped in the CNFs. There is no difference in the binding energy of pyridinic N between them (about 398.5 eV). However, the Fe-N-MCNFs have about 0.3 eV higher binding energy of graphitic N (401.2 eV) than that of the Fe-N-CNFs (400.9 eV). Interestingly, as shown in
Figure S4
, this positive shift of binding energy was only observed after the second heat treatment following the silica leaching process of the Fe-N-MCNFs. Generally, the binding energy of doped N in graphene-like carbon shifts in the positive direction when it combines with a transition metal.
(29)
Therefore, it can be inferred that the binding energy shift of graphitic N would be as a consequence of the formation of Fe-graphitic N
x
bonds during the second heat treatment of the Fe-N-MCNFs. As shown in the Raman spectra, the Fe-N-MCNFs have fewer stacked carbon layers in their graphitic structures than the Fe-N-CNFs. The fewer stacked carbon layers would mean that the Fe-N-MCNFs could have many basal carbon planes that are exposed and out of the graphitic stacks, which would increase the number of basal graphitic N atoms able to combine with the Fe atoms.

The catalytic performance of the Fe-N-MCNFs was investigated in comparison with the Fe-N-CNFs and a commercially purchased Pt/C catalyst. The amount of catalyst loading for the Fe-N-MCNFs and the Fe-N-CNFs was 0.5 mg cm
â2
, while that for the Pt/C was 30 Î¼g
Pt
cm
â2
.
Figure
6
a shows the ORR polarization curves measured in an O
2
-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm. The Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited higher ORR activity than the Fe-N-CNFs over the entire potential area. The half-wave potential (
E
1/2
) increased by about 65 mV, from 0.780 to 0.845 V
RHE
, as a consequence of the mesoporous structuring. The ORR activity of the Fe-N-MCNFs is comparable to that of the Pt/C. The half-wave potential difference between the Fe-N-MCNFs and Pt/C is only 18 mV. The Fe-N-MCNFs can exhibit excellent ORR activity in alkaline solutions. In an acidic solution (0.1 M HClO
4
), the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited lower ORR activity than in an alkaline solution. The half-wave potential is 0.684 V
RHE
, which is approximately 182 mV lower than that of the Pt/C (
Figure
6
b). However, there is a considerable enhancement in the ORR activity of the Fe-N-MCNFs compared to the Fe-N-CNFs in an acidic solution. The Fe-N-CNFs exhibited a half-wave potential of only 0.372 V
RHE
, which is approximately 312 mV lower than that of the Fe-N-MCNFs. Moreover, the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited a limiting current density nearly identical to that of the Pt/C catalyst, whereas the Fe-N-CNFs does not reach a limiting current and the current density was low, less than 4 mA cm
â2
. The limiting current density has a proportional relationship with the number of electrons participating in the ORR. The participation of fewer electrons in the ORR causes lower ORR efficiency due to the greater amount of hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
) produced. The RRDE results in
Figure
6
c,d show that the Fe-N-CNFs exhibited a lower electron number than the ideal value for the ORR, which is 4, thereby producing a fairly high amount of H
2
O
2
(a yield of â¼20%) during ORR. In contrast, the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited a high electron number, closer to 4, and the H
2
O
2
yield was low at about 5â6%. This higher ORR activity and greater efficiency of the Fe-N-MCNFs can be ascribed to the increased electrochemical active surface area at the interface in contact with the electrolyte. As shown in
Figure
6
e, the capacitive current density of the Fe-N-MCNFs is nearly 7 times higher than that of the Fe-N-CNFs, indicating an increase in the interfacial area between the catalyst material and the electrolyte. Hence, this result demonstrates that the electrolyte and O
2
can easily diffuse through the highly mesoporous structures of the Fe-N-MCNFs, leading to an increase in the effective surface area and thus facilitating the ORR.
Figure S5
clearly shows that the synergetic effects of the silica nanoparticles and the PVAc can maximize the effective surface area for the ORR inside the Fe-N-MCNFs, thereby increasing the ORR activity in both alkaline and acidic solutions. Durability is also an important factor to assess the catalytic performance.
Figure
6
f shows the ORR activity of the Fe-N-MCNFs before and after 5000 potential cycles from 0.6 to 1.1 V
RHE
in an O
2
-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
solution. After the 5000 potential cycles, the half-wave potential decreased by only 26 mV. The Fe-N-MCNFs have good durability even in an O
2
-saturated condition. Therefore, it can be concluded that mesoporous structuring is an effective means of enhancing the catalytic activity and efficiency of electrospun CNF-derived M-N-C catalysts for the ORR in alkaline and even acidic solutions. The results in the acidic solution have great significance in that the Fe-N-MCNFs can be applied as inexpensive catalysts under actual PEMFC operating conditions.

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) ORR polarization plots of the Fe-N-MCNFs, the Fe-N-CNFs, and the Pt/C in 0.1 M KOH solution. (b) ORR polarization plots, (c) electron transfer numbers, and (d) H
2
O
2
yields of the Fe-N-MCNFs, the Fe-N-CNFs, and the Pt/C in 0.1 M HClO
4
solution. (e) CVs of the Fe-N-MCNFs and the F-N-CNFs in an acidic solution. (f) Durability of the Fe-N-MCNFs in 0.1 M HClO
4
solution.

div.div:
To assess the feasibility of the Fe-N-MCNFs as durable support materials for PEMFC electrodes, an amount of 10 wt % of Pt nanoparticles was deposited onto Fe-N-MCNFs (denoted as Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs).
Figure
7
a,b shows the ORR activity and the CV curves for the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFS and the Pt/C before and after the potential cycling test. The catalyst loading level was 30 Î¼g cm
â2
for both samples. To assess the corrosion resistance of the carbon supports, the potential cycling test was performed from 0.6 V
RHE
to a highly anodic potential of 1.3 V
RHE
. Before the potential cycles, the ORR activity of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs was nearly identical to that of a commercial Pt/C catalyst. The half-wave potential values of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs and the Pt/C were nearly identical as well at about 0.890 V
RHE
. The initial mass activity at 0.9 V
RHE
of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs was 0.141 A mg
Pt
â1
, and that for the Pt/C was 0.152 A mg
Pt
â1
. The hydrogen adsorptionâdesorption peak area of the CVs, which is closely related to the ECSA of Pt, was also very similar between the two samples. The initial ECSA value of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs was 78.4 m
2
g
Pt
â1
, and that of the Pt/C was 82.8 m
2
g
Pt
â1
. After 2000 potential cycles from 0.6 to 1.3 V
RHE
, the ORR activity and ECSA of both the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs and the Pt/C decreased, as shown in
Figure
7
a, after exposure to the highly anodic potential. However, there were major differences in the ORR activity and ECSA between the two samples later. After the potential cycles, the half-wave potential of the Pt-Fe-N-MCNFs decreased by only 20 mV, whereas that of the Pt/C decreased by 62 mV. For a detailed comparison, the mass activity at 0.9 V
RHE
and the ECSA changes before and after the potential cycles are depicted in
Figure
7
c,d, respectively. After 2000 potential cycles, the mass activity levels of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs and the Pt/C decreased to 0.083 A mg
Pt
â1
and to 0.022 A mg
Pt
â1
, respectively. These results indicate that the Pt/Fe-N-MCNF catalyst retained nearly 60% of the initial ORR activity after the potential cycles, whereas the Pt/C catalyst lost most of its initial activity (approximately 86%) under the same condition. The ECSA value of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs is also higher than that of the Pt/C after the potential cycles. The Pt/C lost 93% of the initial ECSA, but the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs lost only 77% of the initial ECSA. These results clearly show that the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs have excellent stability in the oxidative environment of PEMFCs with a highly anodic potential without sacrificing the initial ORR activity compared to the commercial Pt/C.

div.p:
Figure 7. (a) ORR polarization plots, (b) CVs, (C) Pt mass activity at 0.9 V
RHE
and (d) ECSAs of the Pt/Fe-NMCNFsÂ and the Pt/C before and after the 2000 potential cycles from 0.6 to 1.3 V
RHE
as measured in 0.1 M HClO
4
solution.

div.div:
TEM images of the catalysts before and after the potential cycles show the stability of Pt nanoparticles on each carbon support under the oxidative condition.
Figure
8
a,b correspondingly shows the TEM images of the initial Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs and the Pt/C before the potential cycles. The Pt nanoparticles were uniformly distributed on both carbon supports. The Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs have smaller primary Pt nanoparticles than the Pt/C, which would be ascribed to the surfaces of the Fe-N-MCNFs, which provided more nucleation sites for Pt nanoparticles due to their highly porous structures. After the potential cycles, although the Pt nanoparticle sizes increased to about 8 nm, the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs continued to exhibit a uniform distribution of Pt nanoparticles, as shown in
Figure
8
c. However, the Pt/C lost most of its initial Pt nanoparticles during the potential cycles, as shown in
Figure
8
d. There are only a few remaining Pt nanoparticles, the sizes of which exceed 10 nm. The severe degradation of the Pt/C was most likely caused by the severe corrosion of the carbon support and the agglomeration of the Pt nanoparticles under exposure to the highly anodic potential. These TEM images clearly show that the Pt nanoparticles on the Fe-N-MCNFs are more stable than the commercial Pt/C. In addition, the Pt 4f XPS results in
Figure S6
show that the Pt nanoparticles could have higher chemical interactions with the Fe-N-MCNFs than the commercial carbon support. A strong catalystâsupport interaction is generally regarded as an important factor for determining the stability of nanoparticle catalysts.
(30â32)
Therefore, it can be concluded that the excellent ORR activity of the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs after the potential cycles results from the higher stability of the Pt nanoparticles due to the high corrosion resistance of the support and the strong interaction between the Pt nanoparticles and the support. All of these results demonstrate that the Fe-N-MCNFs are good candidates as durable supports for Pt nanoparticles.

div.p:
Figure 8. TEM images of (a,c) the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs and (b,d) the Pt/C before and after the 2000 potential cycles from 0.6 to 1.3 V
RHE
in 0.1 M HClO
4
solution.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this study, we synthesized highly porous Fe and N codoped mesoporous CNFs for use as both low-cost nonprecious-metal catalysts and durable supports for Pt nanoparticles. To form mesopores effectively inside the CNFs, a combination of two types of porogens, namely, silica nanoparticles and PVAc, was used. As a synergetic effect of those porogens, a high density of mesopores, whose sizes were from 10 to 100 nm, arose inside the CNFs. In addition, the Fe-N-MCNFs have less graphitic layer stacking than the Fe-N-CNFs, which allows the additional formation of Fe-graphitic N
x
bonds due to the exposure of more basal planes of graphite to the outside area of the graphitic stacks. For these reasons, the Fe-N-MCNFs exhibited higher ORR activity than the Fe-N-CNFs in both alkaline and acidic solutions. In an acidic solution, the Fe-N-MCNFs can facilitate almost four electrons involved in the ORR, similar to Pt/C. When the Fe-N-MCNFs were applied as supports, Pt nanoparticles were uniformly distributed on their surfaces due to their high specific surface areas. Therefore, the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs could exhibit ORR activity nearly identical to that by the Pt/C. After potential cycling at a high anodic potential, the Pt/C lost almost all of its initial ORR activity and ECSA. However, the Pt/Fe-N-MCNFs retained approximately 60% of its initial ORR activity. This is ascribed to the excellent stability of the Pt nanoparticles due to the high corrosion resistance of the graphitized Fe-N-MCNFs and the high level of Ptâsupport interaction. This study demonstrates that the Fe-N-MCNFs can be used as effective nonprecious-metal catalysts and durable supports in the acidic environment of PEMFCs.

A metal-free bifunctional electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions
Zhang, Jintao; Zhao, Zhenghang; Xia, Zhenhai; Dai, Liming

The oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are traditionally carried out with noble metals (such as Pt) and metal oxides (such as RuO2 and MnO2) as catalysts, resp. However, these metal-based catalysts often suffer from multiple disadvantages, including high cost, low selectivity, poor stability and detrimental environmental effects. Here, we describe a mesoporous carbon foam co-doped with nitrogen and phosphorus that has a large surface area of â¼1,663 m2 g-1 and good electrocatalytic properties for both ORR and OER. This material was fabricated using a scalable, one-step process involving the pyrolysis of a polyaniline aerogel synthesized in the presence of phytic acid. We then tested the suitability of this N,P-doped carbon foam as an air electrode for primary and rechargeable Zn-air batteries. Primary batteries demonstrated an open-circuit potential of 1.48 V, a specific capacity of 735 mAh gZn-1 (corresponding to an energy d. of 835 Wh kgZn-1), a peak power d. of 55 mW cm-2, and stable operation for 240 h after mech. recharging. Two-electrode rechargeable batteries could be cycled stably for 180 cycles at 2 mA cm-2. We also examine the activity of our carbon foam for both OER and ORR independently, in a three-electrode configuration, and discuss ways in which the Zn-air battery can be further improved. Finally, our d. functional theory calcns. reveal that the N,P co-doping and graphene edge effects are essential for the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity of our material.

A significant problem hindering large-scale implementation of proton exchange membrane fuel cell technol. is the loss of performance during extended operation and automotive cycling. Recent investigations of the deterioration of cell performance have revealed that a considerable part of the performance loss is due to the degrdn. of the electrocatalyst. In this study, an attempt is made to exptl. simulate the degrdn. processes such as carbon corrosion and Pt surface area loss using an accelerated thermal sintering protocol. Two types of Tanaka fuel cell catalyst samples were heat-treated at 250Â° in humidified helium gas streams and several oxygen concns. The catalysts were then cycled electrochem. in pellet electrodes to det. the hydrogen adsorption area and its evolution in subsequent electrochem. cycling. Samples that had undergone different degrees of carbon corrosion and Pt sintering were characterized for changes in carbon mass, active Pt surface area, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, and Pt crystallite size. Studies of the effect of oxygen and water concn. on two Tanaka catalysts, dispersed on carbon supports with varying BET areas, revealed that carbon oxidn. in the presence of Pt follows two pathways: an oxygen pathway that leads to mass loss due to formation of gaseous products, and a water pathway that results in mass gains, esp. for high BET area supports. These processes may be assisted by the formation of highly reactive OH and OOH type radicals. Platinum surface area loss, measured at varying oxygen concns. and as a function of sintering time using x-ray diffraction, CO chemisorption, and electrochem. hydrogen adsorption, reveal an important role for carbon corrosion rather than an increase in Pt particle size for the surface area loss. Platinum surface area loss during 10 h of thermal degrdn. was equiv. to electrochem. degrdn. obsd. over 500 cycles for a Tanaka Pt/Vulcan electrode cycled between 0 and 1.2 V (normal hydrogen electrode). Carbon mass loss obsd. for 5 h of thermal degrdn. was comparable to that obtained during a potential hold for 86 h at 1.2 V (normal hydrogen electrode) and 95Â° for the same catalysts.

A review of one major remaining barrier to commercialization of fuel cells - durability. The correlation of durability with cost cannot be overlooked in developing fuel cell systems, as the two are interrelated in materials. Some of the targets for fuel cell systems as set by the U.S. DOE and Japanese NEDO are discussed. Durability testing and the effect that operating conditions have on fuel cell durability are considered. Internal component durability of fuel cells are discussed with ref. to the polymer- electrolyte membrane, the electrocatalyst and electrocatalyst support, and the gas diffusion media.

Postmortem thickness and morphol. studies on a degraded membrane electrode assembly caused by carbon corrosion under a local H2 starvation operation in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell were carried out using optical, scanning, and transmission electron microscopy. Samples used for the postmortem studies were selected and indexed with the aid of a limiting c.d. distribution map that was premeasured from the degraded membrane electrode assembly using an electrochem. diagnostic technique. An explicit correlation was found between the postmortem studies and the diagnostics; where the electrode structure damage (i.e., thickness redn. and porosity collapse) is significant, the limiting c.d. is low. The structure damage and c.d. drop were found to be in the H2-starved region where the carbon corrosion is severe. The results presented here are of significance in understanding the fundamentals of carbon corrosion mechanism and related structural origin of fuel cell performance degrdn.

Carbon as catalyst and support for electrochemical energy conversion
Trogadas, Panagiotis; Fuller, Thomas F.; Strasser, Peter

A review. Carbon has unique characteristics that make it an ideal material for use in a wide variety of electrochem. applications ranging from metal refining to electrocatalysis and fuel cells. In polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs), carbon is used as a gas diffusion layer, electrocatalyst support, and oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) electrocatalyst. When used as electrocatalyst support, amorphous carbonaceous materials suffer from enhanced oxidn. rates at high potentials over time. This drawback has prompted an extensive effort to improve the properties of amorphous carbon and to identify alternate carbon-based materials to replace carbon blacks. Alternate support materials are classified in carbon nanotubes and fibers, mesoporous carbon, multi-layer graphene (undoped and doped with metal nanoparticles) and reduced graphene oxide. A comparative review of all these supports is provided. Work on catalytically active carbon hybrids is focused on the development of non-precious metal electrocatalysts that will significantly reduce the cost without sacrificing catalytic activity. Of the newer electrocatalysts, nitrogen/metal-functionalized carbons and composites are emerging as possible contenders for com. PEFCs. Nitrogen-doped carbon hybrids with transition metals and their polymer composites exhibit high ORR activity and selectivity and these catalytic properties are presented in detail in this review.

Durability issues have recently been given much attention in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) research. It gives fundamental definition for cell life time, capital cost, system stability and technique reliability. Loss of catalyst surface area due to corrosion of supporting material (normally carbon black) is one of the essential degrdn. mechanisms during cell operation. In this work, durability of carbon nanofibers (CNF) & carbon nanotubes (CNT) as alternative platinum catalyst supports for Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs) was assessed. Platinized CNF and CNT using a std. polyol method were prepd. and fabricated as cathodes of Membrane Electrode Assemblies (MEA) for PEMFC. Both the catalysts as such and the MEAs made out of them were evaluated regarding to thermal and electrochem. stabilities using traditional carbon black (Vulcan XC72) as a ref. Thermal gravimetric anal. (TGA), cyclic voltammetry (CV), polarization curve and impedance spectroscopy were applied on the samples under accelerated stress conditions. The carbon nano-materials demonstrated better stability as a support for nano-sized platinum catalyst under PEMFC related operating conditions. Due to different morphol. of the nano carbons compared to Vulcan XC 72 the electrode structures may still need optimization to improve the overall cell performance.

Polyacrylonitrile (PAN), mixed with Co(II) or Fe(II) salts and high-area C and then heat treated, was found to yield very promising catalysts for O redn. in concd. alk. and acid solns. The catalytic activities are comparable to those for the heat-treated corresponding transition metal macrocycles and polypyrrole black-based catalysts. The addn. of the transition metal to the N-contg. polymer, either before or after the heat treatment with C, is an important factor for good activity. The nitrile N of the PAN is probably retained and converted to pyridyl N during the heat treatment, and this N is believed to provide binding sites for the transition metal ions, which then act as catalytic sites for O2 redn. to peroxide and its decompn.

The prohibitive cost of platinum for catalyzing the cathodic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has hampered the widespread use of polymer electrolyte fuel cells. We describe a family of non-precious metal catalysts that approach the performance of platinum-based systems at a cost sustainable for high-power fuel cell applications, possibly including automotive power. The approach uses polyaniline as a precursor to a carbon-nitrogen template for high-temp. synthesis of catalysts incorporating iron and cobalt. The most active materials in the group catalyze the ORR at potentials within ~60 mV of that delivered by state-of-the-art carbon-supported platinum, combining their high activity with remarkable performance stability for non-precious metal catalysts (700 h at a fuel cell voltage of 0.4 V) as well as excellent four-electron selectivity (hydrogen peroxide yield <1.0%).

A review. A comprehensive overview and description of graphene-based nanomaterials explored in recent years for catalyst supports and metal-free catalysts for polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell oxygen redn. reactions (ORR) is presented. The catalyst material structures/morphologies, material selection, and design for synthesis, catalytic performance, catalytic mechanisms, and theor. approaches for catalyst down-selection and catalyzed ORR mechanisms are emphasized with respect to the performance of ORR catalysts in terms of both activity and stability. When graphene-based materials, including graphene and doped graphene, are used as the supporting materials for both Pt/Pt alloy catalysts and non-precious metal catalyst, the resulting ORR catalysts can give superior catalyst activity and stability compared to those of conventional carbon-supported catalysts; when they are used as metal-free ORR catalysts, significant catalytic activity and stability are obsd. The nitrogen-doped graphene materials even show superior performance compared to supported metal catalysts. Challenges including the lack of material mass prodn., unoptimized catalyst structure/morphol., insufficient fundamental understanding, and testing tools/protocols for performance optimization and validation are identified, and approaches to address these challenges are suggested.

A review. Substitutional heteroatom doping is a promising route to modulate the outstanding material properties of carbon nanotubes and graphene for customized applications. Recently, (nitrogen-) N-doping has been introduced to ensure tunable work-function, enhanced n-type carrier concn., diminished surface energy, and manageable polarization. Along with the promising assessment of N-doping effects, research on the N-doped carbon based composite structures is emerging for the synergistic integration with various functional materials. This invited feature article reviews the current research progress, emerging trends, and opening opportunities in N-doped carbon based composite structures. Underlying basic principles are introduced for the effective modulation of material properties of graphitic carbons by N-doping. Composite structures of N-doped graphitic carbons with various functional materials, including polymers, transition metals, metal oxides, nitrides, sulfides, and semiconducting quantum dots are highlighted. Practical benefits of the synergistic composite structures are investigated in energy and catalytic applications, such as org. photovoltaics, photo/electrocatalysts, lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors, with a particular emphasis on the optimized interfacial structures and properties.

An edge activated S doped Fe-N-graphene (EA-SFeNG) was successfully synthesized via facile ball milling followed by a pyrolysis process. The oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) performance of EA-SFeNG was dramatically improved by doping S and forming edge sites in Fe-N-graphene; the onset potential was shifted from 0.91 VRHE to 1.0 VRHE with the half-wave potential increased from 0.77 VRHE to 0.848 VRHE. The EA-SFeNG exhibited catalytic performances that are comparable to those of com. 20 wt% Pt/C (Vonset: 1.05 V, V1/2: 0.865 V); however, its durability was better than that of the Pt catalyst in alk. media. The excellent ORR activity can be attributed to the increase in defect d. and SOx bonding in the EA-SFeNG. Furthermore, we exptl. demonstrate that the work function of the Fe-N-graphene is significantly reduced from 4.06 eV to 4.01 eV by the increase in edge d. and doping S, thereby improving the ORR kinetics of EA-SFeNG.

Recently, major efforts have been devoted to exploring cheap and active non-precious metal catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in fuel cells for large-scale applications. Herein, we report electrospun cobalt-carbon nanofibers (Co-CNFs) as an efficient catalyst for the ORR, together with a systematic study of the active site formation. The ORR activity of the Co-CNFs increases with increasing Co content up to approx. 30 wt%, at which high ORR activity is exhibited, comparable with a com. Pt/C catalyst in alk. media. XPS and structural anal. reveals a Co-pyridinic Nx bond at the edge plane, and more Co nanoparticles were found in the Co-CNFs as the Co content was increased. These sites can behave as the primary and the secondary active sites for the ORR, according to a dual-site mechanism. The ORR activity of the Co-CNFs may deteriorate even if only one of these sites is limited. The high ORR activity of the Co-CNF catalysts results from the synergetic effect of dual site formation for the ORR.

Nitrogen-doped carbon nanostructures are considered as a possible alternative to platinum-based catalysts for fuel cells. The surface d. of catalytic sites, elec. cond., and nitrogen content play important roles in designing electrode materials for fuel cells. Herein, N-doped carbon fibers are prepd. by electrospinning the poly(acrylonitrile) (PAN) soln. followed by carbonization. Some of the key issues of the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) are addressed in terms of nitrogen content, porosity, and elec. cond. in the N-contg. carbon nanofibrous system. Nitrogen content and the amt. of the graphitic phase are varied by changing the carbonization temp. In addn., N-doped carbon fibers with high porosity are prepd. by electrospinning the soln. mixt. of poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)/PAN followed by carbonization, and the porosity is tuned by varying the ratio of PEO to PAN. The effect of porosity or the surface d. of catalytic sites on the ORR is studied. A medium porous sample prepd. from the PEO/PAN mixt. in a 1:1 ratio by carbonization at 1000 Â°C is found to be favorable for improved ORR performance for such a system. The observations made herein are explained in terms of trade-offs between elec. cond., nitrogen content, and surface d. of active sites.

Ordered mesoporous carbon-carbon nanotube nanocomposites as highly conductive and durable cathode catalyst supports for polymer electrolyte fuel cells
Cheon, Jae Yeong; Ahn, Chiyeong; You, Dae Jong; Pak, Chanho; Hur, Seung Hyun; Kim, Junbom; Joo, Sang Hoon
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability
(
2013
),
1
(
4
),
1270-1283
CODEN:
JMCAET
; ISSN:
2050-7496
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Ordered mesoporous carbon-carbon nanotube (OMC-CNT) nanocomposites were prepd. and used as catalyst supports for polymer electrolyte fuel cells. The OMC-CNT composites were synthesized by a nanocasting method that used ordered mesoporous silica as a template and Ni phthalocyanine as a carbon source. For comparison, sucrose and phthalocyanine were used to generate two other OMCs, OMC(Suc) and OMC(Pc), resp. All three carbons exhibited hexagonally ordered mesostructures and uniform mesopores. Among the three carbons the OMC-CNT nanocomposites showed the highest elec. cond., which was due to the nature of their graphitic framework as well as their lower interfacial resistance. The three carbons were then used as fuel cell catalyst supports. It was found that highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles (â¼1.5 nm in size) could be dispersed on the OMCs by a simple impregnation-redn. method. The activity and kinetics of the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR), measured by the rotating ring-disk electrode technique revealed that the ORR over the Pt/OMC catalysts followed a four-electron pathway. Among the three Pt/OMC catalysts, the Pt/OMC-CNT catalyst resulted in the highest ORR activity, and after an accelerated durability test the differences in the ORR activities of the three catalysts became more pronounced. In single cell tests, the Pt/OMC-CNT-based cathode showed a c.d. markedly greater than those of the other two cathodes after a high-voltage degrdn. test. These results were supported by the fact that the Pt/OMC-CNT-based cathode had the lowest resistance, which was probed by electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. The results of the single cell tests as well as those of the electrochem. impedance spectroscopy-based measurements indicate that the rigidly interconnected structure of the OMC-CNT as well as their highly conductive frameworks are concomitantly responsible for the OMC-CNT nanocomposites exhibiting higher c.d. and durability than the other two carbons.

The electrochromic properties of mesoporous tungsten oxide films are described and compared to std. sol-gel films of WO3. The block copolymer template used in the synthesis was removed by solvent extn. and calcination methods, leading to mesoporous tungsten oxides which range from amorphous to cryst. depending on the removal treatment. The pores are not ordered but do exhibit a fairly regular diam. with an av. size of 4 to 5 nm. The mesoporous tungsten oxides exhibit a well behaved electrochromic response and their electrochem. and optical reversibilities are better than those of the analogous sol-gel film. In addn., the mesoporous films exhibit higher rates for coloration and bleaching. The high surface area of these materials is responsible for this behavior and also leads to multiple peaks in the voltammetric scans.

Design and synthesis of porous channel-rich carbon nanofibers for self-standing oxygen reduction reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction bifunctional catalysts in alkaline medium
Ji, Dongxiao; Peng, Shengjie; Lu, Jia; Li, Linlin; Yang, Shengyuan; Yang, Guorui; Qin, Xiaohong; Srinivasan, Madhavi; Ramakrishna, Seeram
Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability

Carbon-nanofiber-based (CNF-based) nonprecious catalysts and electrodes are essential components in next generation energy conversion and storage technologies. Moreover, porous architectures are highly desirable for active material embedded CNFs. Despite recent progress, controllable synthesis of porous CNFs with favorable mech. properties is still challenging. Herein, we present a general and novel approach to prep. porous and channel-rich CNFs on a large scale through a free-surface electrospinning technique and subsequent carbonization of polyacrylonitrile (PAN)/cellulose acetate (CA) nanofibers. The resultant free-standing and flexible PAN/CA CNFs (CACNFs) possess abundant porous and channel-rich structures, which can be easily controlled by adjusting the wt. ratio of PAN and CA. Based on the porous CACNFs, binder-free Fe3C embedded Fe/N doped CACNF films are successfully prepd. Combining the porous channel-rich structures and the high elec. cond. of the carbon fibers, abundant accessible active sites and fast mass transport pathways are generated in the carbon fibers, leading to favorable catalytic activity and superior stability for ORR (half-wave potential 12 mV more pos. than that of Pt/C) and HER (overpotential 440
[emailÂ protected]
mV cm-2 and more than 100 000 s catalytic stability) in alk. medium, demonstrating their promising potential for application in fuel cells, metal-air batteries and water splitting devices.

Hu, Yang; Jensen, Jens Oluf; Zhang, Wei; Cleemann, Lars N.; Xing, Wei; Bjerrum, Niels J.; Li, Qingfeng
Angewandte Chemie, International Edition

Nonprecious metal catalysts for the oxygen redn. reaction are the ultimate materials and the foremost subject for low-temp. fuel cells. A novel type of catalysts prepd. by high-pressure pyrolysis is reported. The catalyst is featured by hollow spherical morphologies consisting of uniform iron carbide (Fe3C) nanoparticles encased by graphitic layers, with little surface nitrogen or metallic functionalities. In acidic media the outer graphitic layers stabilize the carbide nanoparticles without depriving them of their catalytic activity towards the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). As a result the catalyst is highly active and stable in both acid and alk. electrolytes. The synthetic approach, the carbide-based catalyst, the structure of the catalysts, and the proposed mechanism open new avenues for the development of ORR catalysts.

Mesoporosity as a new parameter for understanding tension stress generation in trees
Chang, Shan-Shan; Clair, Bruno; Ruelle, Julien; Beauchene, Jacques; Di Renzo, Francesco; Quignard, Francoise; Zhao, Guang-Jie; Yamamoto, Hiroyuki; Gril, Joseph
Journal of Experimental Botany

(

; ISSN:
0022-0957
.
(
Oxford University Press
)
The mechanism for tree orientation in angiosperms is based on the prodn. of high tensile stress on the upper side of the inclined axis. In many species, the stress level is strongly related to the presence of a peculiar layer, called the G-layer, in the fiber cell wall. The structure of the G-layer has recently been described as a hydrogel thanks to N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of supercritically dried samples showing a high mesoporosity (pores size from 2-50 nm). This led us to revisit the concept of the G-layer that had been, until now, only described from anatomical observation. Adsorption isotherms of both normal wood and tension wood have been measured on six tropical species. Measurements show that mesoporosity is high in tension wood with a typical thick G-layer while it is much less with a thinner G-layer, sometimes no more than normal wood. The mesoporosity of tension wood species without a G-layer is as low as in normal wood. Not depending on the amt. of pores, the pore size distribution is always centered around 6-12 nm. These results suggest that, among species producing fibers with a G-layer, large structural differences of the G-layer exist between species.

Raman spectroscopy in graphene
Malard, L. M.; Pimenta, M. A.; Dresselhaus, G.; Dresselhaus, M. S.
Physics Reports
(
2009
),

(
5-6

0370-1573

(
Elsevier B.V.

A review. Recent Raman scattering studies in different types of graphene samples are reviewed here. We first discuss the first-order and the double resonance Raman scattering mechanisms in graphene, which give rise to the most prominent Raman features. The detn. of the no. of layers in few-layer graphene is discussed, giving special emphasis to the possibility of using Raman spectroscopy to distinguish a monolayer from few-layer graphene stacked in the Bernal (AB) configuration. Different types of graphene samples produced both by exfoliation and using epitaxial methods are described and their Raman spectra are compared with those of 3D cryst. graphite and turbostratic graphite, in which the layers are stacked with rotational disorder. We show that Resonance Raman studies, where the energy of the excitation laser line can be tuned continuously, can be used to probe electrons and phonons near the Dirac point of graphene and, in particular allowing a detn. to be made of the tight-binding parameters for bilayer graphene. The special process of electron-phonon interaction that renormalizes the phonon energy giving rise to the Kohn anomaly is discussed, and is illustrated by gated expts. where the position of the Fermi level can be changed exptl. Finally, we discuss the ability of distinguishing armchair and zig-zag edges by Raman spectroscopy and studies in graphene nanoribbons in which the Raman signal is enhanced due to resonance with singularities in the d. of electronic states.

Raman spectroscopy as a versatile tool for studying the properties of graphene
Ferrari, Andrea C.; Basko, Denis M.

CODEN:

A review. Raman spectroscopy is an integral part of graphene research. It is used to det. the no. and orientation of layers, the quality and types of edge, and the effects of perturbations, such as elec. and magnetic fields, strain, doping, disorder and functional groups. This, in turn, provides insight into all sp2-bonded carbon allotropes, because graphene is their fundamental building block. Here we review the state of the art, future directions and open questions in Raman spectroscopy of graphene. We describe essential phys. processes whose importance has only recently been recognized, such as the various types of resonance at play, and the role of quantum interference. We update all basic concepts and notations, and propose a terminol. that is able to describe any result in literature. We finally highlight the potential of Raman spectroscopy for layered materials other than graphene.

Few layer graphene was grown on hexagonal boron nitride single crystal flakes by chem. vapor deposition without using metal catalysts. High quality and thickness controllability of the graphene layers are confirmed by Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy. Chem. vapor deposition of graphene on this perfect-lattice-matching dielec. substrate offers many advantages including cost effectiveness, easy scalability and compatibility with std. intergraded circuit processes and promises an advance to graphene's applications in microelectronics and optoelectronics.

A review. Carbon-supported platinum or platinum alloys are generally used as the cathodic electrocatalysts in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) to enhance the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR). Main challenges to be addressed in this area are the high electrochem. activity and high stability maintenance for low-Pt-loading catalysts toward the feasibility for fuel cell operation and the redn. of the system cost. The interaction of Pt with carbon support, as well as the interaction of Pt precursor with carbon during the supported catalyst formation, are considered to be beneficial to the improvement of catalytic activity and durability of the electrocatalysts. This paper provides a review of recent advances related to the physico-chem. and electronic interactions at the catalyst-support interface and the catalyst activity enhancement through improved Pt-C interaction, esp. focusing on the surface modification of the carbon support to form proper functional groups and chem. links at the Pt/C interface.

This study explores a facile method to prep. an efficient and durable support for Pt catalyst of polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC). As a candidate, Nb-doped TiO2 (Nb-TiO2) nanofibers are simply fabricated using an electrospinning technique, followed by a heat treatment. Doping Nb into the TiO2 nanofibers leads to a drastic increase in elec. cond. with doping level of up to 25 at. % (Nb0.25Ti0.75O2). Pt nanoparticles are synthesized on the prepd. 25 at. % Nb-doped TiO2-nanofibers (Pt/Nb-TiO2) as well as on a com. powd. carbon black (Pt/C). The Pt/Nb-TiO2 nanofiber catalyst exhibits similar oxygen reaction redn. (ORR) activity to that of the Pt/C catalyst. However, during an accelerated stress test (AST), the Pt/Nb-TiO2 nanofiber catalyst retained more than 60% of the initial ORR activity while the Pt/C catalyst lost 65% of the initial activity. The excellent durability of the Pt/Nb-TiO2 nanofiber catalyst can be attributed to high corrosion resistance of TiO2 and strong interaction between Pt and TiO2.

Highly efficient and durable TiN nanofiber electrocatalyst supports
Kim, Hyun; Cho, Min Kyung; Kwon, Jeong An; Jeong, Yeon Hun; Lee, Kyung Jin; Kim, Na Young; Kim, Min Jung; Yoo, Sung Jong; Jang, Jong Hyun; Kim, Hyoung-Juhn; Nam, Suk Woo; Lim, Dong-Hee; Cho, Eun Ae; Lee, Kwan-Young; Kim, Jin Young

To date, carbon-based materials including various carbon nanostructured materials have been extensively used as an electrocatalyst support for proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) applications due to their practical nature. However, carbon dissoln. or corrosion caused by high electrode potential in the presence of O2 and/or water has been identified as one of the main failure modes for the device operation. Here, we report the first TiN nanofiber (TNF)-based nonwoven structured materials to be constructed via electrospinning and subsequent two-step thermal treatment processes as a support for the PEMFC catalyst. Pt catalyst nanoparticles (NPs) deposited on the TNFs (Pt/TNFs) were electrochem. characterized with respect to oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) activity and durability in an acidic medium. From the electrochem. tests, the TNF-supported Pt catalyst was better and more stable in terms of its catalytic performance compared to a com. available carbon-supported Pt catalyst. For example, the initial oxygen redn. performance was comparable for both cases, while the Pt/TNF showed much higher durability from an accelerated degrdn. test (ADT) configuration. It is understood that the improved catalytic roles of TNFs on the supported Pt NPs for ORR are due to the high elec. cond. arising from the extended connectivity, high inertness to the electrochem. environment and strong catalyst-support interactions.

A metal-free bifunctional electrocatalyst for oxygen reduction and oxygen evolution reactions
Zhang, Jintao; Zhao, Zhenghang; Xia, Zhenhai; Dai, Liming
Nature Nanotechnology

The oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are traditionally carried out with noble metals (such as Pt) and metal oxides (such as RuO2 and MnO2) as catalysts, resp. However, these metal-based catalysts often suffer from multiple disadvantages, including high cost, low selectivity, poor stability and detrimental environmental effects. Here, we describe a mesoporous carbon foam co-doped with nitrogen and phosphorus that has a large surface area of â¼1,663 m2 g-1 and good electrocatalytic properties for both ORR and OER. This material was fabricated using a scalable, one-step process involving the pyrolysis of a polyaniline aerogel synthesized in the presence of phytic acid. We then tested the suitability of this N,P-doped carbon foam as an air electrode for primary and rechargeable Zn-air batteries. Primary batteries demonstrated an open-circuit potential of 1.48 V, a specific capacity of 735 mAh gZn-1 (corresponding to an energy d. of 835 Wh kgZn-1), a peak power d. of 55 mW cm-2, and stable operation for 240 h after mech. recharging. Two-electrode rechargeable batteries could be cycled stably for 180 cycles at 2 mA cm-2. We also examine the activity of our carbon foam for both OER and ORR independently, in a three-electrode configuration, and discuss ways in which the Zn-air battery can be further improved. Finally, our d. functional theory calcns. reveal that the N,P co-doping and graphene edge effects are essential for the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity of our material.

A significant problem hindering large-scale implementation of proton exchange membrane fuel cell technol. is the loss of performance during extended operation and automotive cycling. Recent investigations of the deterioration of cell performance have revealed that a considerable part of the performance loss is due to the degrdn. of the electrocatalyst. In this study, an attempt is made to exptl. simulate the degrdn. processes such as carbon corrosion and Pt surface area loss using an accelerated thermal sintering protocol. Two types of Tanaka fuel cell catalyst samples were heat-treated at 250Â° in humidified helium gas streams and several oxygen concns. The catalysts were then cycled electrochem. in pellet electrodes to det. the hydrogen adsorption area and its evolution in subsequent electrochem. cycling. Samples that had undergone different degrees of carbon corrosion and Pt sintering were characterized for changes in carbon mass, active Pt surface area, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, and Pt crystallite size. Studies of the effect of oxygen and water concn. on two Tanaka catalysts, dispersed on carbon supports with varying BET areas, revealed that carbon oxidn. in the presence of Pt follows two pathways: an oxygen pathway that leads to mass loss due to formation of gaseous products, and a water pathway that results in mass gains, esp. for high BET area supports. These processes may be assisted by the formation of highly reactive OH and OOH type radicals. Platinum surface area loss, measured at varying oxygen concns. and as a function of sintering time using x-ray diffraction, CO chemisorption, and electrochem. hydrogen adsorption, reveal an important role for carbon corrosion rather than an increase in Pt particle size for the surface area loss. Platinum surface area loss during 10 h of thermal degrdn. was equiv. to electrochem. degrdn. obsd. over 500 cycles for a Tanaka Pt/Vulcan electrode cycled between 0 and 1.2 V (normal hydrogen electrode). Carbon mass loss obsd. for 5 h of thermal degrdn. was comparable to that obtained during a potential hold for 86 h at 1.2 V (normal hydrogen electrode) and 95Â° for the same catalysts.

A review of one major remaining barrier to commercialization of fuel cells - durability. The correlation of durability with cost cannot be overlooked in developing fuel cell systems, as the two are interrelated in materials. Some of the targets for fuel cell systems as set by the U.S. DOE and Japanese NEDO are discussed. Durability testing and the effect that operating conditions have on fuel cell durability are considered. Internal component durability of fuel cells are discussed with ref. to the polymer- electrolyte membrane, the electrocatalyst and electrocatalyst support, and the gas diffusion media.

Postmortem thickness and morphol. studies on a degraded membrane electrode assembly caused by carbon corrosion under a local H2 starvation operation in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell were carried out using optical, scanning, and transmission electron microscopy. Samples used for the postmortem studies were selected and indexed with the aid of a limiting c.d. distribution map that was premeasured from the degraded membrane electrode assembly using an electrochem. diagnostic technique. An explicit correlation was found between the postmortem studies and the diagnostics; where the electrode structure damage (i.e., thickness redn. and porosity collapse) is significant, the limiting c.d. is low. The structure damage and c.d. drop were found to be in the H2-starved region where the carbon corrosion is severe. The results presented here are of significance in understanding the fundamentals of carbon corrosion mechanism and related structural origin of fuel cell performance degrdn.

A review. Carbon has unique characteristics that make it an ideal material for use in a wide variety of electrochem. applications ranging from metal refining to electrocatalysis and fuel cells. In polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs), carbon is used as a gas diffusion layer, electrocatalyst support, and oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) electrocatalyst. When used as electrocatalyst support, amorphous carbonaceous materials suffer from enhanced oxidn. rates at high potentials over time. This drawback has prompted an extensive effort to improve the properties of amorphous carbon and to identify alternate carbon-based materials to replace carbon blacks. Alternate support materials are classified in carbon nanotubes and fibers, mesoporous carbon, multi-layer graphene (undoped and doped with metal nanoparticles) and reduced graphene oxide. A comparative review of all these supports is provided. Work on catalytically active carbon hybrids is focused on the development of non-precious metal electrocatalysts that will significantly reduce the cost without sacrificing catalytic activity. Of the newer electrocatalysts, nitrogen/metal-functionalized carbons and composites are emerging as possible contenders for com. PEFCs. Nitrogen-doped carbon hybrids with transition metals and their polymer composites exhibit high ORR activity and selectivity and these catalytic properties are presented in detail in this review.

Durability issues have recently been given much attention in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell (PEMFC) research. It gives fundamental definition for cell life time, capital cost, system stability and technique reliability. Loss of catalyst surface area due to corrosion of supporting material (normally carbon black) is one of the essential degrdn. mechanisms during cell operation. In this work, durability of carbon nanofibers (CNF) & carbon nanotubes (CNT) as alternative platinum catalyst supports for Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells (PEMFCs) was assessed. Platinized CNF and CNT using a std. polyol method were prepd. and fabricated as cathodes of Membrane Electrode Assemblies (MEA) for PEMFC. Both the catalysts as such and the MEAs made out of them were evaluated regarding to thermal and electrochem. stabilities using traditional carbon black (Vulcan XC72) as a ref. Thermal gravimetric anal. (TGA), cyclic voltammetry (CV), polarization curve and impedance spectroscopy were applied on the samples under accelerated stress conditions. The carbon nano-materials demonstrated better stability as a support for nano-sized platinum catalyst under PEMFC related operating conditions. Due to different morphol. of the nano carbons compared to Vulcan XC 72 the electrode structures may still need optimization to improve the overall cell performance.

Polyacrylonitrile (PAN), mixed with Co(II) or Fe(II) salts and high-area C and then heat treated, was found to yield very promising catalysts for O redn. in concd. alk. and acid solns. The catalytic activities are comparable to those for the heat-treated corresponding transition metal macrocycles and polypyrrole black-based catalysts. The addn. of the transition metal to the N-contg. polymer, either before or after the heat treatment with C, is an important factor for good activity. The nitrile N of the PAN is probably retained and converted to pyridyl N during the heat treatment, and this N is believed to provide binding sites for the transition metal ions, which then act as catalytic sites for O2 redn. to peroxide and its decompn.

The prohibitive cost of platinum for catalyzing the cathodic oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) has hampered the widespread use of polymer electrolyte fuel cells. We describe a family of non-precious metal catalysts that approach the performance of platinum-based systems at a cost sustainable for high-power fuel cell applications, possibly including automotive power. The approach uses polyaniline as a precursor to a carbon-nitrogen template for high-temp. synthesis of catalysts incorporating iron and cobalt. The most active materials in the group catalyze the ORR at potentials within ~60 mV of that delivered by state-of-the-art carbon-supported platinum, combining their high activity with remarkable performance stability for non-precious metal catalysts (700 h at a fuel cell voltage of 0.4 V) as well as excellent four-electron selectivity (hydrogen peroxide yield <1.0%).

A review. A comprehensive overview and description of graphene-based nanomaterials explored in recent years for catalyst supports and metal-free catalysts for polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) fuel cell oxygen redn. reactions (ORR) is presented. The catalyst material structures/morphologies, material selection, and design for synthesis, catalytic performance, catalytic mechanisms, and theor. approaches for catalyst down-selection and catalyzed ORR mechanisms are emphasized with respect to the performance of ORR catalysts in terms of both activity and stability. When graphene-based materials, including graphene and doped graphene, are used as the supporting materials for both Pt/Pt alloy catalysts and non-precious metal catalyst, the resulting ORR catalysts can give superior catalyst activity and stability compared to those of conventional carbon-supported catalysts; when they are used as metal-free ORR catalysts, significant catalytic activity and stability are obsd. The nitrogen-doped graphene materials even show superior performance compared to supported metal catalysts. Challenges including the lack of material mass prodn., unoptimized catalyst structure/morphol., insufficient fundamental understanding, and testing tools/protocols for performance optimization and validation are identified, and approaches to address these challenges are suggested.

A review. Substitutional heteroatom doping is a promising route to modulate the outstanding material properties of carbon nanotubes and graphene for customized applications. Recently, (nitrogen-) N-doping has been introduced to ensure tunable work-function, enhanced n-type carrier concn., diminished surface energy, and manageable polarization. Along with the promising assessment of N-doping effects, research on the N-doped carbon based composite structures is emerging for the synergistic integration with various functional materials. This invited feature article reviews the current research progress, emerging trends, and opening opportunities in N-doped carbon based composite structures. Underlying basic principles are introduced for the effective modulation of material properties of graphitic carbons by N-doping. Composite structures of N-doped graphitic carbons with various functional materials, including polymers, transition metals, metal oxides, nitrides, sulfides, and semiconducting quantum dots are highlighted. Practical benefits of the synergistic composite structures are investigated in energy and catalytic applications, such as org. photovoltaics, photo/electrocatalysts, lithium ion batteries and supercapacitors, with a particular emphasis on the optimized interfacial structures and properties.
